title: Is the judgment money an unsecured debt or a secured one?
question: I've filed a chapter 13, and my major creditor has a judgement against me for breach of contract and Corporate violation- I have to pay him the judgement money, which is his money he gave me plus some interest.
answers: You really should consult a qualified bankruptcy attorney regarding your specific situation. If I understand the question correctly, in a sense, it is both. That is the judgment is an unsecured debt, however, if an abstract or other security device is duly recorded (and there is actual security) it might be considered a secured debt. You should definitely speak with an attorney as to the characterization of that particular debt (considering all of your particular circumstances) when filling out official bankruptcy forms and papers.
It would be a general unsecured debt unless the creditor filed a lien at the registry of deeds or the court otherwise gave the creditor a lien on your assets during the course of the case.

The judgment is an unsecured claim, unless the judgment creditor recorded a lien on real property or secured a lien on some other property in accordance with the law of the state where the debtor’s property is located (an involuntary secured claim). In other words, the creditor has to take one step further to turn a judgment into a lien. Recording a lien is called "perfecting the lien".

I've filed a chapter 13, and my major creditor has a judgement against me for breach of contract and Corporate violation- I have to pay him the judgement money, which is his money he gave me plus some interest.
Is this debt an unsecured debt or a secured one?

Response: This is an unsecured debt.

Until the judgment is recorded, it is considered unsecured. Once an abstract of the judgment is recorded, it becomes a lien on any real property owned by the judgment debtor in that county. In that sense the debt becomes "secured" because the judgment creditor can foreclose on the lien (depending on several factors, not the least of which is: Does the equity in the property exceed your statutory and/or recorded homestead exemption.)
